content: Art is not what you see, but what you make others see.
author: Edgar Degas
bio: Edgar Degas was a French Impressionist painter and sculptor, renowned for his masterful depiction of movement, particularly of dancers. Though associated with the Impressionist movement, he preferred to be called a realist. He often painted rehearsals and everyday life, capturing fleeting moments with innovative composition and technique.
artInfo: This painting captures a candid rehearsal moment among ballerinas, highlighting Degas' fascination with movement and behind-the-scenes life in the Paris Opera.

content: Creativity takes courage.
author: Henri Matisse
bio: Henri Matisse was a leading figure in modern art and the founder of Fauvism, a movement known for its wild brushwork and vibrant colors. Over his career, he transitioned from painting to paper cut-outs due to health issues, pushing the boundaries of abstraction and visual emotion.
artInfo: The Snail is a late work created with paper cut-outs, arranged in a spiral form to represent a snail. It reflects Matisse’s turn to simplified forms and bold colors in his later years.

content: The purpose of art is washing the dust of daily life off our souls.
author: Pablo Picasso
bio: Pablo Picasso was a Spanish painter, sculptor, and co-founder of the Cubist movement. One of the most prolific and influential artists of the 20th century, he constantly evolved in style—experimenting with realism, surrealism, abstraction, and beyond. His works often conveyed deep personal and political meaning.
artInfo: Les Demoiselles d'Avignon is a groundbreaking Cubist work that portrays five nude female figures in a fractured, angular form. It challenged traditional composition and sparked the beginning of modern abstract art.

content: Every artist was first an amateur.
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
bio: American essayist and philosopher who inspired artistic independence.

content: I dream my painting and I paint my dream.
author: Vincent van Gogh
bio: Vincent van Gogh was a Dutch Post-Impressionist painter whose emotionally resonant works and expressive use of color profoundly influenced modern art. Though largely unrecognized in his lifetime and plagued by mental health struggles, he produced over 2,000 pieces, including some of the most beloved paintings in history.
artInfo: Starry Night is one of Van Gogh’s most iconic works, depicting a swirling night sky over a quiet village. It exemplifies his emotional intensity and imaginative vision.

content: I paint flowers so they will not die.
author: Frida Kahlo
bio: Mexican painter known for self-portraits and surrealism.

content: Great art picks up where nature ends.
author: Marc Chagall
bio: Russian-French artist blending fantasy and folklore.

content: Art enables us to find ourselves and lose ourselves at the same time.
author: Thomas Merton
bio: Trappist monk and writer who explored the spiritual value of art.

content: Art should comfort the disturbed and disturb the comfortable.
author: Banksy
bio: Anonymous British street artist known for provocative murals.

content: Color is a power which directly influences the soul.
author: Wassily Kandinsky
bio: Russian pioneer of abstract art and spiritual color theory.

content: To be an artist is to believe in life.
author: Henry Moore
bio: English sculptor known for large-scale bronze figures.

content: Painting is self-discovery. Every good artist paints what he is.
author: Jackson Pollock
bio: Abstract expressionist known for his drip-painting technique.

content: Art is the lie that enables us to realize the truth.
author: Pablo Picasso
bio: Pablo Picasso was a Spanish painter, sculptor, and co-founder of the Cubist movement. One of the most prolific and influential artists of the 20th century, he constantly evolved in style—experimenting with realism, surrealism, abstraction, and beyond. His works often conveyed deep personal and political meaning.
artInfo: Les Demoiselles d'Avignon is a groundbreaking Cubist work that portrays five nude female figures in a fractured, angular form. It challenged traditional composition and sparked the beginning of modern abstract art.

content: Art must be life — it must belong to everybody.
author: Marina Abramović
bio: Performance artist pushing limits of body and mind.

content: The world doesn’t make sense, so why should I paint pictures that do?
author: Pablo Picasso
bio: Pablo Picasso was a Spanish painter, sculptor, and co-founder of the Cubist movement. One of the most prolific and influential artists of the 20th century, he constantly evolved in style—experimenting with realism, surrealism, abstraction, and beyond. His works often conveyed deep personal and political meaning.
artInfo: Les Demoiselles d'Avignon is a groundbreaking Cubist work that portrays five nude female figures in a fractured, angular form. It challenged traditional composition and sparked the beginning of modern abstract art.

content: An artist is not paid for his labor but for his vision.
author: James Whistler
bio: 19th-century American artist known for his tonal harmony.

content: Art is the most beautiful of all lies.
author: Claude Debussy
bio: Impressionist composer who also expressed deep artistic philosophies.

content: A work of art which did not begin in emotion is not art.
author: Paul Cézanne
bio: French Post-Impressionist who laid groundwork for modern art.

content: Art is to console those who are broken by life.
author: Vincent van Gogh
bio: Vincent van Gogh was a Dutch Post-Impressionist painter whose emotionally resonant works and expressive use of color profoundly influenced modern art. Though largely unrecognized in his lifetime and plagued by mental health struggles, he produced over 2,000 pieces, including some of the most beloved paintings in history.
artInfo: Starry Night is one of Van Gogh’s most iconic works, depicting a swirling night sky over a quiet village. It exemplifies his emotional intensity and imaginative vision.

content: Art is not freedom from discipline, but disciplined freedom.
author: John F. Kennedy
bio: U.S. President who advocated for arts and culture.

content: Art speaks where words are unable to explain.
author: Mathiole
bio: Contemporary digital artist with cosmic and dreamlike themes.

content: Art is therapy.
author: Tracey Emin
bio: British artist known for confessional and raw autobiographical work.

content: The only time I feel alive is when I’m painting.
author: Vincent van Gogh
bio: Vincent van Gogh was a Dutch Post-Impressionist painter whose emotionally resonant works and expressive use of color profoundly influenced modern art. Though largely unrecognized in his lifetime and plagued by mental health struggles, he produced over 2,000 pieces, including some of the most beloved paintings in history.
artInfo: Starry Night is one of Van Gogh’s most iconic works, depicting a swirling night sky over a quiet village. It exemplifies his emotional intensity and imaginative vision.

content: Painting is just another way of keeping a diary.
author: Pablo Picasso
bio: Pablo Picasso was a Spanish painter, sculptor, and co-founder of the Cubist movement. One of the most prolific and influential artists of the 20th century, he constantly evolved in style—experimenting with realism, surrealism, abstraction, and beyond. His works often conveyed deep personal and political meaning.
artInfo: Les Demoiselles d'Avignon is a groundbreaking Cubist work that portrays five nude female figures in a fractured, angular form. It challenged traditional composition and sparked the beginning of modern abstract art.

content: Inspiration exists, but it has to find you working.
author: Pablo Picasso
bio: Pablo Picasso was a Spanish painter, sculptor, and co-founder of the Cubist movement. One of the most prolific and influential artists of the 20th century, he constantly evolved in style—experimenting with realism, surrealism, abstraction, and beyond. His works often conveyed deep personal and political meaning.
artInfo: Les Demoiselles d'Avignon is a groundbreaking Cubist work that portrays five nude female figures in a fractured, angular form. It challenged traditional composition and sparked the beginning of modern abstract art.

content: I don’t paint things. I only paint the difference between things.
author: Henri Matisse
bio: Henri Matisse was a leading figure in modern art and the founder of Fauvism, a movement known for its wild brushwork and vibrant colors. Over his career, he transitioned from painting to paper cut-outs due to health issues, pushing the boundaries of abstraction and visual emotion.
artInfo: The Snail is a late work created with paper cut-outs, arranged in a spiral form to represent a snail. It reflects Matisse’s turn to simplified forms and bold colors in his later years.

content: Drawing is the honesty of the art.
author: Jean-Auguste-Dominique Ingres
bio: French Neoclassical painter with exceptional draftsmanship.

content: A true artist is not one who is inspired, but one who inspires others.
author: Salvador Dalí
bio: Surrealist master of melting clocks and dream logic.

content: The object of art is not to reproduce reality, but to create a reality of the same intensity.
author: Alberto Giacometti
bio: Swiss sculptor known for elongated human forms.

content: Life beats down and crushes the soul and art reminds you that you have one.
author: Stella Adler
bio: Acting teacher and advocate for artistic purpose.
